channel.title: Interview on R-Ladies Lausanne
channel.description: Recent content in Interview on R-Ladies Lausanne

item.title: Interview with Leonore Wigger (presenter #1)
item.description:
The learning process is always two fold. On the one side it’s really just learning about statistical concepts and methods, but then on the other hand it’s also about to program the analysis in R. At our very first meetup, Leonore Wigger gave a short presentation on how to arrange multiple ggplot plots onto multipage PDFs.
R-Ladies Lausanne: What is the work that you do? Leonore Wigger: I work 50% at the Swiss Institute of Bioinformatics and the other 50% I work at the University of Lausanne, at the Lausanne Genomics technology facility, which is a service provider for lab experiments.

item.title: Interview with Rosalie Burel
item.description: I feel that learning to program in R provided me with a mindset that helps me understand today’s technology much better. Rosalie Bruel has a background in ecology research, where she just finished her PhD on lakes ecological response to climate change. As one of our first supporters, she missed our lightening talk session in June as she will soon head to Vermont. Luckily for us, she proposed to do a twitter thread instead on her work in environmental research.

item.title: Interview with Elisabeth Dahlqwist (presenter #2)
item.description:
The reason I presented at R-Ladies, is, that when I had done my first shiny app, I felt it was really amazing and I really wanted to share my experience of doing that, because it was quite easy. Elisabeth Dahlqwist gave an introduction to Shiny at our second R-Ladies Lausanne meetup.
Sina Rüeger: What is the work that you do? Elisabeth Dahlqwist: I’m a PhD student in Biostatistics at Karoliska Institute in Stockholm.
